questions.text: What is the sequence of staining of cornea?
questions.solution:
Double vital staining: Use of 1% fluorescein + 1% lissamine green together in diagnosis of ocular surface disorders. This is done for combined assessment of corneal and conjunctival surface evaluation. The two vital dyes, fluorescein and lissamine green, complement each other, with fluorescein staining between cells and achieving clearer staining of the cornea, and lissamine green staining the cells themselves and appearing particularly clearly on the conjunctiva.

Rose Bengal stain is used to stain mainly dead and desquamated cells. It has certain level of cellular toxicity. So it is used last in the sequence.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

Option A. Lissamine Green > Rose Bengal > Fluorescein - Incorrect because fluorescein, which stains epithelial defects, should be applied first to avoid interference from other dyes.

Option B. Rose Bengal > Lissamine Green > Fluorescein - Incorrect because Rose Bengal is toxic and should be applied last to prevent discomfort and interference with the other stains.

Option D. Fluorescein > Rose Bengal > Lissamine Green - Incorrect because Rose Bengal should be applied last due to its cellular toxicity, while lissamine green is preferred before it for evaluating conjunctival staining.

Key Takeaway:

The correct sequence of corneal staining is Fluorescein > Lissamine Green > Rose Bengal to ensure optimal assessment while minimizing cellular toxicity and patient discomfort.

https://www.reviewofophthalmology.com/article/the-dye-namics-of-dry-eye-diagnosis#:~:text=The%20two%20vital%20dyes%2C%20fluorescein,particularly%20clearly%20on%20the%20conjunctiva.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are direct goniolens?
a. Koeppe
b. Zeiss
c. Goldman
d. Richardson
questions.solution:
Direct - Koeppe lens

Indirect lens - Goldmann

Image and text references: AAO eyewiki Gonioscopy

questions.text: Which nerves are tested in vestibulo - ocular reflex?
questions.solution:
The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) is a crucial reflex that stabilizes gaze during head movements by generating compensatory eye movements in the opposite direction. It involves the vestibular system (CN VIII - Vestibulocochlear Nerve) and cranial nerves controlling eye movement (CN III, IV, VI).

  • Cranial Nerve 3 (Oculomotor Nerve) plays a significant role by controlling the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles, which contribute to eye movement in response to head motion.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

Option A. Cranial Nerve 1 (Olfactory Nerve) - Incorrect because CN 1 is responsible for the sense of smell and has no role in the vestibulo-ocular reflex.

Option B. Cranial Nerve 2 (Optic Nerve) - Incorrect because CN 2 is responsible for vision, not for controlling eye movement in response to vestibular stimuli.

Option D. Cranial Nerve 4 (Trochlear Nerve) Alone - Incorrect because while CN 4 (Trochlear Nerve) contributes to certain eye movements, the VOR requires coordination of CN III (Oculomotor), CN IV (Trochlear), and CN VI (Abducens).

Key Takeaway:

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) primarily tests Cranial Nerves 3, 4, and 6, which control extraocular muscles to stabilize vision during head movement. However, if the answer must be chosen from the given options, CN 3 (Oculomotor Nerve) is the best choice.

questions.text: What is the gain of velocity in oculovestibular reflex?
questions.solution:
• The vestibulo-ocular reflex(VOR) is a reflex acting to stabilize gaze during head movement, with eye movement due to activation of the vestibular system.
  • The reflex acts to stabilize images on the retinas of the eye during head movement.
  • when the head moves to the right, the eyes move to the left, meaning the image a person sees stays the same even though the head has turned.
  • VOR gain is defined as the change in the eye angle divided by the change in the head angle during the head turn. Ideally the gain of the rotational VOR is 0.

Key Takeaway:

The normal gain of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) is 1, ensuring that eye movements precisely compensate for head movements, maintaining clear vision.

The gain of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) is defined as:

VOR Gain=Change in Eye AngleChange in Head AngleVOR Gain=Change in Head AngleChange in Eye Angle

  • Ideally, VOR gain = 1, meaning that for every degree the head moves in one direction, the eyes move an equal amount in the opposite direction to stabilize vision.
  • If gain >1, the eyes move more than needed, causing overcompensation.
  • If gain <1, the eyes move less than needed, leading to visual instability (oscillopsia).

questions.text: What is this structure shown in the image
questions.solution:
• Retrolental space is also known as berger space
  • The space between zonular fork is called as canal of hannover
  • Space between posterior zonules and anterior hyaloid is called as canal of petit

questions.text: The following is the image of a patient before and after phenylephrine. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Instillation of phenylephrine in eyes of a patient with episcleritis causes blanching and temporarily eases the congestion in eye. This test is thus used to differentiate from scleritis.

  • Episcleritis is a common, benign, self limiting condition of the episcleral tissue.
  • Females> males
  • M/c cause - idiopathic. Others: associated systemic disorder like collagen vascular disease.
  • Differential diagnosis for cases of episcleritis includes conjunctivitis, phlyctenular conjunctivitis, scleritis.

Phenylephrine - alpha1 agonist drug. Causes vasoconstriction, leadings to blanching of superficial vessels in episcleritis, not in scleritis.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

  • Scleritis - Incorrect because scleral blood vessels do not blanch with phenylephrine. Scleritis also presents with deep, boring pain and is more often associated with systemic autoimmune diseases.
  • Phlycten - Incorrect because phlyctenular conjunctivitis is an inflammatory response to bacterial proteins (e.g., tuberculosis, staphylococcus). It presents as small nodules at the limbus with surrounding hyperemia, not diffuse redness.
  • Dermoid - Incorrect because a dermoid cyst is a congenital, benign tumor typically seen at the limbus, appearing as a yellowish-white mass. It does not cause diffuse eye redness and does not respond to phenylephrine.

Key Takeaway:

The phenylephrine test helps differentiate episcleritis (blanching) from scleritis (no blanching). Episcleritis is usually idiopathic and resolves on its own, whereas scleritis requires further evaluation for systemic disease.

choices.text: Early and specific VF defect is isopteric contraction
For monitoring glaucoma VF defects kinetic perimetry is the best
In static perimetry the stimulus is moving with variable intensity
VF defects are usually associated with ONG changes in the optic nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is true about open angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
• In open-angle glaucoma (OAG), optic nerve head (ONG) changes such as neuroretinal rim thinning, increased cup-to-disc ratio, and retinal nerve fiber layer defects are characteristic findings.
  • These changes precede or accompany visual field (VF) defects, which progress from paracentral scotomas to arcuate scotomas and eventually tunnel vision.
  • VF defects correlate with ganglion cell loss and optic disc damage seen in glaucoma progression.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

  • Early and specific VF defect is isopteric contraction - Incorrect
    • Isopteric contraction is seen in retinitis pigmentosa or other diffuse retinal diseases, not specific to glaucoma.
    • Early VF defects in OAG include small paracentral scotomas, nasal steps, and arcuate scotomas (Bjerrum scotomas).
  • For monitoring glaucoma VF defects, kinetic perimetry is the best - Incorrect
    • Kinetic perimetry (e.g., Goldmann perimetry) is used for conditions like neuro-ophthalmic diseases, not ideal for glaucoma monitoring.
    • Static perimetry (e.g., Humphrey Visual Field 24-2, 30-2 tests) is the gold standard for detecting and monitoring glaucomatous VF defects.
  • In static perimetry, the stimulus is moving with variable intensity - Incorrect
    • Static perimetry presents a stationary stimulus at different locations with variable brightness (intensity) to determine threshold sensitivity.
    • The moving stimulus concept applies to kinetic perimetry, where a stimulus of fixed intensity moves from non-seeing to seeing areas.

Key Takeaway:

Open-angle glaucoma is characterized by optic nerve head changes that correlate with specific visual field defects(early paracentral scotomas, arcuate scotomas, nasal steps). Static perimetry (Humphrey) is the preferred method for glaucoma monitoring, not kinetic perimetry.
